author: Robert Farrington
title: High School Freshman: Start Earning Money For College
text:
With the cost of college rising, and families becoming more and more pressed to pay for tuition, high school students need to get to work. From high school jobs, to scholarship searches, there is money out there - but it all depends on how much you want to earn it.One of the big gaps when it comes to earning money is when to start. [tweet_Quote: display="Too many high school students start too late in their hunt for money to pay for college. via @Forbes"]Too many high school students start too late in their hunt for money to pay for college.[/tweet_Quote: ]
In reality, it's never too early to start. Scholarships The first thing most people think of when it comes to paying for college are scholarships. Universities and organizations give billions to students ever year in the form of scholarships. And the amount of scholarships available keeps rising. That's why it's so important to start early.For students, though, the hard part is finding them. Many scholarships allow you to start applying as early as freshman year of high school (if not sooner). It never hurts to start looking!There are many resources to help students find college scholarships - from websites like Fastweb , which is one of the largest scholarship matching services online, to Raise.me , which gives micro-scholarships to students throughout high school for micro-achievements like good grades.Students should also not forget about local organizations, charities, and even the companies that their parents' work for to find scholarships.[caption id="attachment_6c04e7abca53427ba4bf94d7c4a6fbaf" align="" width="640"] Jadyn W., SleepIQ Kids Tonight Bedtime, Tomorrow the World Scholarship Contest winner, and family visit the Sleep Number Store at the Natick Mall to receive her $50,000 scholarship and SleepIQ Kids Bed on Sunday, Oct. 4, 2015 in Natick, Mass. (Marc Andrew Deley/AP Images for Sleep Number)[/caption] Work High schoolers should also get to work! There are countless jobs available for high school students if they're willing to put in the work. From retail, to internships, many employers are looking for young adults to hire.Work also gives high school students great soft skills that employers are looking for . Communication and problem solving are two areas that aren't taught well in the classroom, but most employers say are essential for graduates to be successful in the workplace.Plus, earning a paycheck is a great way to save for rising college tuition. Online Gigs Finally, millennials are online, and there is a growing on-demand economy that they can be a part of. There are countless ways for high school students to earn money online. Here's over 50 ideas right here .From selling crafts online on shops like Etsy, to creating a blog and sharing their ideas, millennials can take advantage of this changing economy. There are even places for students to sell their notes for classes they take, or do micro-gigs for a small fee.The fact is, the Internet has opened up an opportunity for young adults to earn money on their own time - which is important for high school students. They can work after school, and after homework and practice. They can earn a little bit every day. The Internet makes it possible. The Bottom Line The bottom line is that students need to start earning early to help pay for the future. Yes, parents can help. And yes, there are student loan options out there.But high school students shouldn't neglect their own earning power when it comes to their future - there are so many potential ways to make it happen.
